When evaluating a job offer, focusing on the CTC (Cost-to-Company) alone can be misleading.

It‚Äôs important to understand how much you‚Äôll actually take home after deductions and how non-cash components influence your overall compensation.

Let‚Äôs break this down with an example and detailed calculations.

ùêîùêßùêùùêûùê´ùê¨ùê≠ùêöùêßùêùùê¢ùêßùê† ùê≠ùê°ùêû ùêíùêöùê•ùêöùê´ùê≤ ùêÇùê®ùê¶ùê©ùê®ùêßùêûùêßùê≠ùê¨:

Assume a CTC of ‚Çπ15,00,000/year:
Basic Salary (40% of CTC): ‚Çπ6,00,000
HRA (20% of CTC): ‚Çπ3,00,000
Special Allowances: ‚Çπ5,00,000
PF Contribution (Employer‚Äôs Share): ‚Çπ72,000
Gratuity: ‚Çπ28,860

ùêÉùêûùêùùêÆùêúùê≠ùê¢ùê®ùêßùê¨ ùêüùê´ùê®ùê¶ ùêíùêöùê•ùêöùê´ùê≤:

PF Contribution (12% of Basic): ‚Çπ72,000
Income Tax (as per new regime of FY24): Approx. ‚Çπ1,16,200 (considering standard deduction and slab rates).
Professional Tax: ‚Çπ2,400 (varies by state).

ùêìùêöùê§ùêû-ùêáùê®ùê¶ùêû ùêíùêöùê•ùêöùê´ùê≤ ùêÇùêöùê•ùêúùêÆùê•ùêöùê≠ùê¢ùê®ùêß:

CTC = ‚Çπ15,00,000
Deductions (PF, Tax, etc.) = ‚Çπ1,90,600
In-Hand Salary (Net Pay) = ‚Çπ13,09,400/year = ~‚Çπ1,09,117/month

ùêëùê®ùê•ùêû ùê®ùêü ùêçùê®ùêß-ùêÇùêöùê¨ùê° ùêÇùê®ùê¶ùê©ùê®ùêßùêûùêßùê≠ùê¨:

Non-cash components like health insurance, ESOPs, wellness programs, travel reimbursements, and meal cards add value but don‚Äôt reflect in your take-home pay.

Example: A ‚Çπ2,00,000 health insurance benefit might save you expenses on medical emergencies but doesn‚Äôt affect your monthly income.

ùêäùêûùê≤ ùêàùêßùê¨ùê¢ùê†ùê°ùê≠ùê¨ ùêüùê®ùê´ ùêçùêûùê†ùê®ùê≠ùê¢ùêöùê≠ùê¢ùê®ùêß:

[1] Focus on In-Hand Salary:
A higher in-hand salary gives you more financial freedom for monthly expenses, savings, and investments.

[2] Evaluate Non-Cash Benefits:
These can significantly reduce out-of-pocket expenses and should be factored into your decision.

[3] Consider Long-Term Components:
Gratuity and PF contributions are valuable for future security but won‚Äôt impact your immediate cash flow.

[4] Understand Tax Efficiency:
Check if the salary structure includes tax-saving allowances like HRA or LTA to optimize your take-home pay.

ùêÇùê®ùêßùêúùê•ùêÆùê¨ùê¢ùê®ùêß:

Negotiating a job offer isn‚Äôt just about the CTC number‚Äîit‚Äôs about understanding what truly benefits you both now and in the long term.

Always analyze the in-hand salary, evaluate non-cash components, and consider your financial goals before making a decision.

ùêñùê°ùêöùê≠ ùêùùê® ùê≤ùê®ùêÆ ùê©ùê´ùê¢ùê®ùê´ùê¢ùê≠ùê¢ùê≥ùêû‚ÄîùêÇùêìùêÇ ùê®ùê´ ùê¢ùêß-ùê°ùêöùêßùêù ùê¨ùêöùê•ùêöùê´ùê≤?

postsData.content:
Role plays aren't broken. Your measurement system is!


I recently had a great conversation with my amazing friend(Sandler Calgary President, Author, and Sales Leadership Coach) about a framework most sales leaders ignore: measuring role play effectiveness through conversion ratios.


Here's the reality check: You can't improve what you don't measure, and "soft skills" don't mean unmeasurable results.


Key insights from our discussion:

- Track ratio improvements between each sales stage (e.g., demo-to-proposal etc)
- Small improvements compound - a 10% boost in one conversion metric can significantly impact overall results
- Combine quantitative metrics with qualitative field observations
- Give your team time to implement changes - coaching isn't a one-time event


In the full episode, we covered:

- Why group role plays might be hurting your team more than helping
- The psychology behind effective 1:1 role play sessions
- How AI is transforming sales practice and coaching
- Why top performers need different types of role play scenarios
- The "leader models first" framework for building trust


Check out the full conversation in the comments

postsData.content:
An ETP (Effluent Treatment Plant) is a facility designed to treat wastewater generated from industrial processes before it is discharged into the environment or reused. The primary goal of an ETP is to remove contaminants and pollutants to meet regulatory standards for effluent discharge. Here's an overview of its components and working:
Key Components
Preliminary Treatment: This stage includes screening and grit removal to eliminate large solids and debris that could damage equipment.
Primary Treatment: In this phase, sedimentation tanks are used to settle out heavier solids. This helps in reducing the suspended solids and organic load.
Secondary Treatment: This biological treatment stage uses microorganisms to degrade organic matter. Common methods include:
Activated Sludge Process: Air is introduced to mix wastewater with microorganisms.
Biofilm Processes: Bacteria grow on surfaces (e.g., trickling filters) to treat wastewater.
Tertiary Treatment: This advanced treatment phase targets remaining contaminants, including nutrients and pathogens. Methods may include filtration, chemical treatment, or disinfection.
Sludge Management: The residual sludge from the treatment processes is further processed (e.g., anaerobic digestion, dewatering) for disposal or reuse.
Benefits
Environmental Protection: Reduces pollution and protects water bodies from industrial effluents.
Water Reuse: Treated water can be reused for various applications, such as irrigation or industrial processes.
Regulatory Compliance: Helps industries meet environmental regulations and standards.
ETPs are crucial for sustainable industrial practices, ensuring that wastewater is treated effectively before it impacts the environment.

postsData.content:
I had a delightful time back on the Ohio University campus with my favorite group of Brazilian learners LAIOB - Latin America Institute of Business. 

This time I had the distinct pleasure of teaching 160 management and project management students across two full days of workshops covering enterprise AI strategy, how to work with AI, and how to manage AI projects successfully.

The most remarkable and challenging aspect of teaching these classes remains the pace of change.

When I first designed these workshops in 2021, few people had heard of GPT-3. Although they were marveled by the demos, few saw the connection to their day to day life.

Contrast that to my classes this week. Many come from organizations actively deploying novel generative AI tools, with maturing AI governance structures and working groups. About half the class are already using AI for at least 10% of their tasks, and a good number are using it for more than a quarter of their work.

I was blown away by the quality of questions and the depth of the discussion. I'm already eagerly planning the updates to these workshops to stay relevant for this summer.
postsData.commentAdded: What an inspiring experience! The rapid evolution of AI and its integration into daily tasks is truly impressive. Excited for your future workshops!

postsData.content:
One of The Most Underrated Skill in Business? Knowing When to Walk Away. 

In business, there‚Äôs often a fear that saying ‚Äúno‚Äù means missing out. Founders worry they won‚Äôt get another investment offer. Investors hesitate to cut losses on a failing bet. Executives hold onto outdated strategies, hoping they‚Äôll eventually work.

I‚Äôve seen founders accept bad deals because they feared they wouldn‚Äôt get another. The wrong investor can derail your business more than no investor at all.

I‚Äôve seen investors double down on losses instead of pivoting their capital to higher-impact ventures. Sunk-cost fallacy is real.

I‚Äôve seen companies cling to outdated strategies, pouring millions into marketing campaigns that no longer resonate with their audience.

The smartest move sometimes is to pivot or pull back.

Saying no is just as powerful as saying yes.

Great founders, investors, and business leaders know this: Walking away isn‚Äôt failure but strategy.
I've spent my career as an expert building brands, transforming companies and helping executives and founders conduct turnarounds to achieve accelerated growth. Let's just say, my experience is like a PhD in business success.

What‚Äôs one decision you made to walk away that ultimately paid off? Drop it in the comments.

postsData.content:
My Best Life Lesson: Stop Fighting Problems-Work WITH Them!
The harder you push, the worse it gets. 
Just like in this video: Instead of desperately climbing out of an ice pit, you adopt a slow, circular motion.

Less force = More stability.
Effortless escape-thanks to basic physics.

This principle isn‚Äôt just physics-it‚Äôs a life hack: stop resisting, find your balance, and let momentum propel you to breakthrough solutions.

Here‚Äôs how to stop forcing solutions and start working with them:

1Ô∏è‚É£ Stop Forcing: Struggling only drains your energy without fixing the problem.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Embrace Reality: Accept the situation as it is. Resistance only clouds creative solutions.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Reframe the Problem: A fresh perspective can reveal opportunities you never saw before.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Break It Down: Overwhelming challenges become manageable when tackled piece by piece.

5Ô∏è‚É£ Take Steady Steps: Progress isn‚Äôt about grand leaps‚Äîit‚Äôs built on consistent, deliberate action.

6Ô∏è‚É£ Seek Support: A fresh perspective can lighten the load and open doors to innovative solutions.

Explore the Benefits of the Portugal Golden Residence Permit Program

The Portugal Golden Residence Permit Program (commonly known as the Portugal Golden Visa Program) offers a unique opportunity for non-EU nationals to live, work, and invest in Portugal. This 5-year residence by investment program not only grants you the right to reside in Portugal but also provides visa-free circulation within Europe‚Äôs Schengen Area. With minimal residency requirements ‚Äî just seven days per year ‚Äî it‚Äôs a flexible option for those seeking global mobility and a high quality of life.

 Key Benefits:
- Visa-free travel within the Schengen Area
- Right to live, work, and study in Portugal
- Eligibility for citizenship after 5 years (while retaining other citizenships)
- Low physical presence requirement (just 14 days in the first 2 years, 21 days in the next 3 years)
- Access to top-tier education (both international and Portuguese schools)
- High quality of life with great food, culture, climate, and security
- Excellent healthcare facilities

 Investment Options: Applicants can choose from a variety of investment options, including:

Capital Transfer:

1. EUR 500,000 for investment funds or venture capital with a minimum of 60% of the portfolio in Portuguese companies
2. EUR 500,000 for research activities
3. EUR 250,000 in cultural or artistic support

Business Investment:

1. Creation of at least 10 new jobs (8 in low-population density areas)
2. EUR 500,000 for a business creation that generates 5 permanent jobs for 3 years or an increase in share capital that maintains 10 jobs

 Why Portugal?
- High quality of life
- Rich cultural heritage
- Safe and secure environment
- Mild climate and wonderful local cuisine
- Internationally recognized healthcare system

postsData.content:
BIOMIMICRY CONTINUUM ‚Äì Part 5 ‚Äì CURATING Agentic Expertise
Multidisciplinary expertise is critical to correctly define the key premises driving problem analysis and solution architecture, and the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem (left image) enables capturing that expertise as a reusable computing asset.

The current AI chaos is due to 70 years of narrow and unexamined premises. The promise of AGI in the 1950s was rooted in premises that have been disproven by real-world evidence but blindly adhered to by those making today‚Äôs AGI claims. Key examples:

-Premise: language is the source of intelligence
-Reality: intelligence is the source of language - babies are intelligent before they can speak

-Premise: data is a representation of the real world
-Reality: data is the output of a machine and represents only what the machine was designed to capture

-Premise: the brain constructs objects by identifying frequent patterns of object bits
-Reality: the brain contains networks of abstract concept cells which fire when the concepts are presented in diverse versions and formats (text, image, sound, etc.)

-Premise: neural networks imitate how the brain reasons by processing massive data exhaustively
-Reality: the brain computes the relevance of inputs using inhibition networks, filtering out over 99.99% of sensory data

There are more, but the point is that the main objectives of curation are:
1-Ensure that knowledge from all relevant domains is included in the ontology
2-Map the relevant knowledge concepts across the domains to problem and solution concepts
3-Maintain the landscape concepts (science, business, regulation, etc.) reasonably updated

To enable these objectives, the custodian systems must support:
1-Biomimetic digital twinning of problem and solution concepts
2-Independent update by authorized experts
2-Simulation and testing of the impact of proposed updates across the ontology architecture

The methodology and technology to build this type of biomimetic digital twin ecosystem exist, we have produced published results, and I have discussed this in my posts.

The vision of the Agentic Expertise Ecosystem in the image, however, is in early stages and will require committed partners with the necessary resources who want to participate in shaping the implementation of this new paradigm.
postsData.commentAdded: Exciting insights into the future of AGI! Emphasizing multidisciplinary approaches is key for overcoming outdated premises. Lets collaborate!

Dan Goodman
postsData.content:
AE terminated after only 10 months and being assured job was safe after leads were manipulated and denied. 

Another example of a company screwing up, intentionally or not, and holding it against an employee to justify a termination, after they assured the employee, they would not.

I consulted with an account executive named Randy. He was terminated after only 10 months of employment after being assured his job was safe.

For the most recent quarter, Randy and the rest of his team received no leads as they were all quietly and underhandedly funneled to another team by another manager.

Randy fought and complained about this for weeks as he had no leads to work. He was assured any poor performance for the quarter would not be held against him and they would fix the lead allocation process moving forward.

He was terminated within 2 weeks after the assurances were made. Randy was offered only two weeks‚Äô severance despite assurances he will have at least another quarter to perform given the unfair lack of opportunity.

Was Randy set up for failure to be fired?

Was he terminated because he exposed the lead manipulations and continued to complain about it?

Who knows, but whatever it was, he did not deserve to be terminated after just 10 months of employment with how things went down.

We had a call, and I shared some strategies and tactics he should use to get a better offer. He is deciding what his next steps will be.

comments.commentText:
There is no such thing as job security in this day and age. 

My second point is that in 23 years of selling at my current company closing over 200m in software contracts, I had a total of 1 lead that resulted in a closed sale. 1. And that was back in 2003. If you are a hunter you go out and generate your own leads and not sit back and wait and complain about how leads are allocated.

So instead of worrying about the things he could control, he decided to complain about the process. It seems like Randy has a case of the ‚Äúeveryone is out to get me‚Äù. He should of kept his head down and not worried about where leads were going and go find his own. Was the rest of the team fired as well since they didn‚Äôt get leads? Sounds like Randy should learn from this and not rely so heavily on leads and have the mentality that I need to find my own leads and everything else is gravy if it comes to me. Also he can say something one time about leads but to continuously bring it up for weeks, it then becomes a major problem and makes him look bad.

postsData.commentAdded: Such a frustrating situation for Randy! It highlights the importance of transparency in leadership. Wishing him the best in finding a supportive environment!

postsData.content:
In an insightful interview with businessline, Indian Institute of Technology, Madras Prof. Balaraman Ravindran, Head of the Wadhwani School of Data Science and AI, IIT Madras, explains how DeepSeek has disrupted the AI industry by making model training and inference drastically cheaper‚Äîpotentially reducing costs to just one-tenth of OpenAI‚Äôs models. Prof. Ravindran highlights why this breakthrough is such a big win for India!

DeepSeek‚Äôs Mixture-of-Experts approach activates only a fraction of the model, significantly reducing computational costs, thus, by implementing aggressive quantization down to 4-bit precision, it lowers memory and processing power requirements, making AI more resource-efficient. Moreover, their focus on smarter inference through efficient reinforcement learning ensures, that fewer resources are needed for accurate results. The open-source access provided by DeepSeek also empowers Indian researchers and startups, creating vast opportunities for innovation.

These advancements make AI more accessible, positioning India to compete globally. At IIT Madras, we are already developing evaluation frameworks for GenAI models tailored to India, ensuring AI is fair, robust, and applicable to real-world needs.

What do you think this means for India's AI future?

Read the full interview here:.

2025 Micro-Machine Holdcos Model:

#MLDS2025, Pranshu Agrawal Lead AI Engineer at MathCo explored strategies for enhancing AI systems in the airline industry by integrating organizational context to improve accuracy and relevance. He highlighted the limitations of generic AI models, which often generate inaccurate responses due to a lack of metadata, domain expertise, and contextual understanding. To address these challenges, he introduced a structured framework that begins with onboarding data to ensure AI systems have access to relevant organizational knowledge.

He emphasized the importance of metadata, domain knowledge, user personas, and conversation history in refining AI-generated insights.

Additionally, Pranshu introduced autonomous agents and real-time data integration, demonstrating how these advancements can enhance operational efficiency within the aviation sector.

postsData.content:
Bad employer behavior is the fault of the employee. Say What?!?!?!?

We collectively have allowed it to get to where it has gone.

Employees who are wronged or victimized by their employer and continue to allow it to happen or just walk away in silence are encouraging the employer to continue to do it.

When they steal your commission and you accept it with little push back, you‚Äôre inviting it to happen again. You are rewarding them. You are making it financially more lucrative to do the wrong thing.

They get away with it because we let them.

They‚Äôve done it for so long they don‚Äôt even give it a second thought. It becomes second nature. They can detach the human consequences of their actions and how it impacts the employees who have shown up for them every day for years or even decades.

It is a mental illness to be able to do so. Narcissists. Sociopaths. Lacking a conscious and humanity and fairness. Sadly, this represents way too many leaders in the corporate world, who BTW are proud of it.

It‚Äôs time to expose them and their harmful actions that cause permanent scars on their victims. You know what makes these bullies cower? Do you know what their kryptonite is? Public exposure. It is their greatest fear.

It is your right to share your truthful experience. You have no obligation to hide their wrongdoing and abuse. In fact, I would say the opposite. We all have an obligation to protect and warn each other from the abuse of these so-called leaders.

It‚Äôs time for employees to stop walking away feeling like a victim and carrying that regret for years or decades or forever. Document, call it out, confront it, be heard.

Hold them accountable for their actions. It could be one of the most empowering things you do in your life.

comments.commentText: Thanks for the repost Selvalakshmi Vivek. I appreciate it.

Dan, you're a good man.

Last year, I stumbled upon Professor Roy Casagranda. In one of his lectures, he lays out a dark truth about the formation of the United States. This country was built on stolen land and stolen labor. The American way was to receive what was never yours and exploit those who had no choice.

At its core, America is transactional. From the beginning, success was defined by how much one could take while giving as little as possible in return. This mindset shaped our economy, our institutions, and even our culture. It is why negotiation, leverage, and self-interest are seen as virtues. It is why maximizing profit and minimizing cost is the guiding principle of American business.

This same transactional mindset fuels how employers treat workers today. Companies squeeze employees for every ounce of productivity while paying as little as they can get away with. They preach loyalty while offering none in return. The absurd behaviors of employers stem from the transactional mindset. Employees are seen as assets to be optimized, not people to be valued. Just as in the past, those with power extract as much as possible from those without, all while insisting that‚Äôs just the way things are.
Danie van der Merwe agreed
Kutty T Stauder that‚Äôs one of the most thoughtful comments I‚Äôve read in a long time. Thank you for it. You‚Äôre absolutely on the mark.

postsData.content:
Most people blindly use ChatGPT without understanding which model works best. Don‚Äôt be one of them.
GPT-4o, o1, o3-mini‚Äîwhat do they even mean? And which one actually fits your needs?

Let‚Äôs break it down once and for all.

‚Ü≥ GPT-4o (The Default & Most Powerful Model)
 What It Does:
 Understands text, images, and audio‚Äîat the same time.
 Faster & cheaper than GPT-4 while handling complex conversations.

 Who Should Use It?
 Content Creators: Writing, brainstorming, scripting.
 Business Professionals: Emails, strategy planning, presentations.
 Developers: Coding, debugging, AI integrations.
 Students & Researchers: Study assistance, summarizing papers.

 Why is it useful?
 Feels more natural‚Äîlike talking to a real assistant.
 Works with images & audio, making it next-gen multimodal AI.


‚Ü≥ o1 (The Deep Thinker)
 What It Does:
 Specializes in advanced reasoning, coding, and problem-solving.
 More precise but slower than GPT-4o.

 Who Should Use It?
 Developers & Engineers: Writing, debugging, and optimizing code.
 Mathematicians & Scientists: Complex equations, structured problem-solving.
 Researchers: Argumentation, data analysis, report writing.

 Why It Stands Out:
 Eliminates logical errors in complex reasoning tasks.
 Ideal for technical users needing highly accurate outputs.


‚Ü≥ o3-mini & o3-mini-high (The Optimized Fast Thinkers)
 What They Do:
 Lighter versions of o1‚Äîbuilt for speed & efficiency.
 o3-mini-high offers slightly better accuracy.

 Who Should Use Them?
 Developers & Engineers: Quick AI coding assistance.
 Business Analysts: Fast data analysis without heavy computation.
 Casual AI Users: Reliable logic-based responses without high processing power.

 Why They‚Äôre Useful:
 Faster & cheaper than o1 while still offering solid reasoning skills.

‚Ü≥ GPT-4o Mini (The Budget-Friendly Choice)
 What It Does:
 A stripped-down version of GPT-4o for cost-effective AI.
 Perfect for chatbots, basic automation, and casual conversations.

 Who Should Use It?
 Businesses running AI chatbots: Affordable AI for customer support.
 Startups & SMEs: AI without heavy processing costs.
 Casual Users: Quick, low-cost AI responses.

 Why It‚Äôs Valuable:
 Faster, cheaper, and great for basic tasks.
 Perfect for scaling AI without major expenses.

‚Ü≥  So, Which One Should You Use?
 For General Use & Business? ‚Üí GPT-4o
 For Advanced Reasoning & Coding? ‚Üí o1
 For Fast, Efficient AI? ‚Üí o3-mini / o3-mini-high
 For Budget-Friendly AI? ‚Üí GPT-4o Mini


 Which model do you use the most? Drop it in the comments!
Hey, I‚ÄômMohammad.
I share my journey‚Äîdocumenting AI breakthroughs and the future of innovation. Join me, and let‚Äôs grow together.

postsData.content:
Why top performers leave: 

(and how to keep them)

Losing your best people isn‚Äôt about pay‚Äî

It‚Äôs about leadership.

When high performers walk away, it‚Äôs rarely random.

Here‚Äôs why they leave‚Äîand what leaders can do to keep them:

1. They feel undervalued.

Recognition matters. If they‚Äôre constantly delivering but never acknowledged, they‚Äôll find a place that appreciates them.

How to fix it:

Celebrate their contributions‚Äîprivately and publicly.

2. They‚Äôre overworked.

Top performers often get more responsibility‚Äîbut without the support to match.

How to fix it: Reward efficiency with balance, not just more work.

3. They don‚Äôt see a future.

If they feel stagnant, they‚Äôll start looking for growth elsewhere.

How to fix it: Create clear paths for advancement and skill development.

4. They‚Äôre stuck under bad leadership.

People don‚Äôt leave companies‚Äîthey leave managers who don‚Äôt support them.

How to fix it: Train leaders to coach, not just manage.

5. They want more impact.

Top performers crave meaningful work. If they don‚Äôt feel challenged, they‚Äôll move on.

How to fix it: Involve them in high-impact projects where they can grow and contribute.

Retaining top talent isn‚Äôt about perks‚Äî

It‚Äôs about culture, leadership, and opportunity.

Do you agree? Let me know below.

Repost to help others
Followfor more insights

The ONE thing most of my clients miss in the sales process?


Before I tell you, have you heard the term MEDDIC?

(Metric, Economic Buyer, Decision Criteria, Decision Process, Identify Pain, Champion)

MEDDIC is used primarily in complex B2B sales to help sales teams understand the customer's buying process (and influence them to buy).

What it assumes is that you've had a conversation with a person who can buy, one that is meaningful to them.

And everyone says, "Oh, I got it, just ask more questions."

But they don't:

Ask the right questions
At the right time
In the right order
About the right things

And what happens is, they rush to present or propose.

‚Üí They don't slow down enough to have the real conversation that no one else is having.

If we can have a better conversation early.

Then you get picked because you're the only person that looks, sounds and feels different.

They, literally,  have no other way to tell you apart.

And that‚Äôs what I do best.

Teach people and sales teams to have conversations that convert.

Imposter Syndrome Is Silently Killing Your Career.

5 Power Moves to Break Free.

That voice in your head gets louder each day:
"I'm not ready"
"I'm not qualified"
"Someone will find out"

Imposter syndrome thrives on self-doubt, and fear‚Äî
but you don‚Äôt have to give it all your power.

Here's how to take back control:

1. Challenge Your Inner Narrative
‚Ü≥ Your feelings of inadequacy aren't facts
‚Ü≥ Replace "I got lucky" with evidence of your achievements

2. Define Success Differently
‚Ü≥ Your worth isn't measured by achievements alone
‚Ü≥ Create metrics that matter to your growth

3. Take Strategic Action
‚Ü≥ You overthink until opportunities pass
‚Ü≥ Start sharing work at 80%, iterate forward

4. Step Into Discomfort
‚Ü≥ Growth waits outside your comfort zone
‚Ü≥ Choose one uncomfortable action daily

5. Create Success Rituals
‚Ü≥ You let doubt control your daily choices
‚Ü≥ Build morning practices that fuel confidence


Your imposter syndrome isn't truth.
It's just a story you can rewrite.

postsData.content:
A thread on money and lessons learned from the past 16 years. 

(Read this to get smarter with your money)

-

1. Real Estate is a trap for most people.

Look it is an incredible way to build wealth.

It is also an incredible way to add complexity, create headaches, and earn less than you should.

2. Most people don't know what they want.

We make money and all we want is more. Ask someone why and they usually say something like "a better life".

Ask what "a better life" looks like and most struggle to define it.

3. Financial advice is amplified through shared experiences.

Most people don't need someone to tell them basic money strategy.

They need an intellectual sparring partner not to make the big mistake (spending too little, spending too much, taking on unnecessary risk)

4. Money changes people.

No, it doesn't turn you into a terrible person.

It amplifies your connections, changes your circle, and gives you experiences that change your viewpoint on life.

5. The smartest people don't make the most money.

Ignore the outlier cases (Zuckerberg and Musk), the richest people realized this:

Everyone puts their pants on the same way ~ if they can do it so can you.

6. The happiest people are not the richest.

The greatest thing money can do is provide peace of mind and control of your time.

The desire for more is a drug and the only cure is understanding what is enough.

7. No one wins an award for dying with the most money.

Contrary to how many people live their lives, there is no medal stand at death.

There are the people you impacted, the contributions you made, and the things you helped make better.

8. The best way for most people to make money is boring.

News flash you don't need to be on the Forbes 30 under 30 list for some new breakthrough.

Buying a boring small business, spend less than you make, invest in a diversified portfolio ~ It works.

9. The shiniest pitches should be avoided.

How does a casino pay for a nice building? By luring you in with shiny objects.

The same is true for most pitches ~ lavish pitches to get you to buy/invest is a red flag.

10. You should come up with your list.

These are my experiences with money.

My experiences are .00000001% of all the experiences out there ~ create your list and stick by it.

-

 If you find this helpful, please share it with your network Ô∏è and follow me for more ways to get smarter with your money.

‚Üí Slow periods are perfect for training.

postsData.name:
Arvind Narayanan
Arvind Narayanan
postsData.content:
We're seeing the same form-versus-function confusion with Deep Research now that we saw in the early days of chatbots. Back then people were wowed by chatbots' conversational abilities and mimicry of linguistic fluency, and hence underappreciated the limitations. Now people are wowed by the "report" format of Deep Research outputs and its mimicry of authoritativeness, and underappreciate the difficulty of fact-checking 10-page papers. So I think some of the initial excitement will fade (which is not to deny that the tool is extremely useful).

A subtle but more important reason to be excited about Deep Research is that it represents one of the first attempts to merge the two main directions of progress beyond model scaling, namely reasoning and agentic capabilities, and thus sets an extremely low bar for what reasoning agents are capable of. There is lots of low hanging fruit ahead.

Why should we not be proud of the open source leaders that will likely come out of China now? Why should we not be impressed by DeepSeek? A company founded in 2023 a full 8 years after OpenAI. Have you looked into the pace of iteration and either Qwen or their lab? It makes the billions that Meta has put into this look fragile.

So Silicon Valley is going to have to ban all of them just to create a moat? It was in May 2023 that the Google employee warned us of there not being moat.

No, no let's actually look deeper into the implications of what this means.
Wrong thread?

Excellent analogy with early chatbots! The 'wow factor' of Deep Research outputs can definitely overshadow the practical challenges, like verifying the accuracy of long, complex reports. I also appreciate your optimism about the future of reasoning agents. While the current bar is low, I think the real challenge will be balancing these advancements with usability‚Äîensuring that these tools remain accessible and practical for a wide range of users.

Lots of exciting work ahead!

Behind every resume is a human being.

A person with hopes, dreams, and a family.

Here‚Äôs what most people don‚Äôt realize about hiring:

‚Ü≥ Every application carries a story.
‚Ü≥ Every interview holds a dream.
‚Ü≥ Every decision impacts a life.

Great leaders don‚Äôt just scan resumes ‚Äî they see people.

They:

‚Ä¢ Hire with empathy, not just checklists.
‚Ä¢ Look beyond experience to find potential.
‚Ä¢ Understand that rejection affects real lives.

I‚Äôve seen people break when they were treated as just another resume.

And at the same time‚Ä¶

I‚Äôve seen careers transform when someone takes a chance on the right person.

A company will never become great in the first case.
And it will never stop growing in the second.

Why?

Because the best hires are the ones
who just need someone to believe in them.
